post.author: Stefferi
post.title: The Tactics of Sander's Socialist Branding

div.p: I'm going to take a stab on why it was a smart thing for Bernie to campaign using the word 'socialist' from the get-go. I mean, many people have wondered why didn't just call himself a "New Deal Democrat" or something if much of what he proposes is closer to the New Deal than the Soviet Union, since that would be less abrasive.

Basically, Bernie saw that there was a great deal of anti-party anger - aimed at DNC as well as RNC - that he could tap into. By specifically taking an abrasive but ideologically somewhat undefined term - like 'socialist' - he could turn it into a label for, basically, people who want to vote for the Democrats - but not these lizards. People who feel angry and dismissive about slick, focus-group-tested, jargon-spouting career-track Democrats, exemplified by the Hillary 2016 presidential campaign.

If you were against all that, you could now vote for Bernie, and a part of Bernie's appeal was that he would basically go "yeah, I'm a socialist, so what?" after decades of Republicans slurring capitalist Democrats as socialists and Democrats weakly countering that no, we're not socialists, we love freedom! It sounds different, it sounds strange, there's a "did-he-just-do-that?" reaction - that's why it's appealing to Bernie voters, it wouldn't pass focus groups! That's also why, when you look into Bernie voters, you find a surprising amount of more conservative Democrats, or at least that applied in 2016; those types have also felt angry about DNC's variant of urban city-slicker liberalism, and Bernie offered them a way to go against them.

Of course, the main matching pattern on the Republican side is obvious - the current President - but I think that what's happened with the word 'socialist' is the same as with the word 'libertarian' on the GOP side, for some time - similarly, it's obvious to me that 'libertarian' had less a connotation of the strict doctrinaire libertarianism that you find in ideological libertarian circles and more of "Republican, but not these lizards", often specifically aimed at the equally fake and artificial Evangelical GOP subculture that had a lot of strength in the party.

Of course, that didn't necessary mean that people calling themselves libertarians would be very libertarian, as Libertarian Party has had to find out a number of times, and it's no surprise that many of Ron Paul supporters, for example, would go over to Trump as soon as there was a better way to indicate that you are Republican, but not these lizards.
